issues.title: (PUP-7349) Generated tidy resources should have the same noop-ness
issues.body:
If tidy resource's noop metaparameter is true or false, but not nil,
then generate file resources with the same noop-ness. If the noop
metaparameter is not set, but the Puppet noop setting is, then just
let puppet handle it.

issues.title: (PUP-8267) Leverage beaker subcommands when running acceptance
issues.body:
PR #6477 needs to be merged first.

Leverages beaker project options (.beaker.yml) and beaker subcommands so that if you execute a test run, e.g. `bundle exec rake ci:test:aio ...`, but a test fails, you can easily re-run the failing test, as many times as you need, `bundle exec beaker exec tests/path/to/test.rb`.

The `ci:test:quick` task does not work correctly due to BKR-1393, but it is not currently used in CI. The `ci:test:git` task doesn't completely work due ruby platform specific issues that will be resolved later when we move to the `puppet-runtime`

issues.title: (maint) Pass through text domain when loading translations
issues.body:

issues.title: (PUP-8356) Base fips specific behaviors without using facts
issues.body:
We need to adjust some settings based on whether fips mode is enabled
or not for FIPS compliance. Till now the later was done using a fact (PUP-8141).
However that created a dependency in puppetserver which cannot load facts in certain configurations like dev testing and running from sources.
This change implements fips mode detection using a local method instead of facter.

issues.title: (PUP-3802) Fix yaourt on Arch linux.
(PUP-8337) Change Windows symlink? check behavior
issues.body:
- Previously, any file that returned FILE_ATTRIBUTE_REPARSE_POINT
   in a call to GetFileAttributes would be considered a "symlink" for
   Puppets purpose. This is relevant specifically to file resources.

   However, Puppet cannot resolve the destination location for many of
   the reparse point types, namely the following (some of which may
   not actually resolve to a different path):

   IO_REPARSE_TAG_HSM
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_HSM2
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_SIS
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_WIM
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_CSV
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_DFS
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_DFSR
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_DEDUP
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_NFS

 - Modify the behavior of symlink? such that Puppet only considers
   reparse points IO_REPARSE_TAG_MOUNT_POINT, IO_REPARSE_TAG_SYMLINK
   as resolvable symlinks.

   The others will continue to be treated as regular files /
   directories.

 - Existing symlink? behavior has been factored out to a reparse_point?
   method responsible for only validating the file attribute contains
   the reparse attribute.

 - This introduces some additional work once a path is determined as a
   reparse point, but this should not happen regularly as reparse
   points are typically fairly rare on Windows systems.

 - Change the behavior of exist? to function similarly to symlink? in that
   only understandable symlinks will be followed. exist? will return true
   for reparse points that are not mount or symlink reparse points

issues.title: (maint) Allow numeric hostnames in hiera_in_templates test
issues.body:
This test creates a hash of hostname -> directory, and stores it in
YAML for hiera to query. If the hostname happens to be purely numeric,
the key in the hash will be a number, rather than a string. Facter
always returns the `hostname` fact as a string. This causes the hash
lookup in the puppet code to fail, and the manifest to fail to
compile.

The fix is to prepend a bit of non-numeric junk to the hostname, so
that the key in hiera is always string.

issues.title: (PUP-8223) Improve user and group forcelocal support
(PUP-8114) Make enabled state check accurate for SLES 11 boot services in redhat service provider
issues.body:
(PUP-8114) Make enabled state check accurate for SLES 11 boot services in redhat service provider

Without this patch applied, the redhat service provider is not idempotent
in enabling SLES 11 boot services. These are special Sys V services beginning
with the string 'boot.'. When `chkconfig` is run against them, they print
'<name>  B' instead of '<name>  on', so the existing regex does not match them.
Thus the redhat provider always sees them as disabled, and tries to enable
them on each agent run.

This patch adds the '<name>  B' condition to the regex.

```
$ chkconfig boot.kdump
boot.kdump  B
```

Before:
```
$ puppet agent -t --debug 2>&1 | grep -i kdump | grep -i enable
Notice: /Stage[main]/Kdump/Service[kdump]/enable: enable changed 'false' to 'true'
```

After: 
```
$ puppet agent -t --debug 2>&1 | grep -i kdump | grep -i enable
```

issues.title: (WIP) ci:test:git for SLES11
(PUP-7648) Fix ci:test:git pre-suite on OSX 10.11
issues.body:
- A number of problems prevented ci:test:git from executing properly
   on OSX 10.11:

   * When performing a `gem install bundler`, system Ruby places the
     binstub in /usr/local/bin. However, the SSH environment is not
     configured with /usr/local/bin in PATH. There are multiple
     solutions to this problem:

      - Add /usr/local/bin to ~/.ssh/environment in Beaker - covered
        in BKR-1139. This allows any additional binaries that might
        be installed (homebrew, git, other Ruby gems with binstubs
        such as puppet and facter) to be available. This is the most
        effective universal solution but requires a Beaker release.

        A workaround is in place to do this in 000_EnvSetup of the
        pre-suite until Beaker changes land.

      - Add to the host[:host_env] hash of environment variables via
        a Beaker options file, so that PATH is augmented with
        /usr/local/bin. Unfortunately this requires setting additional
        hosts / options files on disk prior to any code running in
        the Puppet pre-suite, to be picked up during Beakers host
        initialization and injected into ~/.ssh/environment correctly.
        Otherwise, the PATH would have to be manipulated in each new
        SSH command. Due to beaker-hostgenerator commonly being used
        to execute, its simpler to avoid this option.

        Note that beaker-hostgenerator should also allow arbitrary
        settings injection using {} syntax, but this doesn't appear to
        work properly with ci:test:git and it's uncertain if it
        properly handles the :host_env hash when writing to YAML.

   * When performing `bundle install`, ensure Ruby is configured to
     use OSX platform specific gems where possible. This impacts
     the inclusion of CFPropertyList.

   * Due to OSX SIP (System Integrity Protection) /usr/bin is not
     writable and /usr/local/bin should be used instead. Override
     Beakers default puppetbindir setting to /usr/local/bin and use
     that as the --binstub directory when installing the Puppet source
     with Bundler. binstubs should continue to use /usr/bin/ruby as
     the interpreter.

   * Similarly, when calling install.rb, provide --bindir as the same
     /usr/local/bin as the system Ruby binstub dir is not otherwise
     writable. Beaker helpers will fully qualify the path to puppet
     using the puppetbindir setting already.

issues.title: (PUP-7519) Enabling rubocop securitycop scans
issues.body:
Background: Rubocop scans were not running as the various cops in .rubocop.yml were not kept uptodate with the latest definitions. This will enable only SecurityCop/YAMLLoad as a start to revive the scans in an effort to flag any inadvertent usages.  Additional security or other cop rules can/would be added in future.   
Rubocop do not have support for flagging YAML.load_file which would have been desirable. Likewise it is not necessary to mark the known instance of Yaml.load_file in Puppet::Util::Yaml to be ignored.

Note that there are a couple of other YAML.load instances elsewhere so this may generate violations. If that is not desired this PR be merged after all these have been resolved/changed appropriately.

issues.title: (PUP-6134) Explicitly locate gemcmd windows
issues.body:
On Windows:

Puppet is unable to install a ruby gem anywhere other than Puppet's ruby.
Caused by Puppet prepending its paths (including our gem) to PATH.
This fix removes Puppet's paths from PATH when setting :gemcmd.

(A larger-scale solution would involve a path/target parameter to Package.)

issues.title: (DO NOT MERGE)(maint) Set BUNDLE_SPECIFIC_PLATFORM=true
issues.body:
**This might be one to outright close, but note that without it we're not using platform-specific Facter which depends on CFPropertyList**

 - Bundler, under some circumstances, may not install platform-specific
   gems.  For instance, using a bundle install of the Puppet Gemfile
   will not install the universal-darwin version of Facter.

 - Set the environment variable BUNDLE_SPECIFIC_PLATFORM also
   had to be set to properly use platform-specific versions of any
   gems that have been referenced.  This will be the default behavior
   in Bundler 2, and given platform-specific versions of Facter are
   shipped - should always be the case for Puppet. Without setting
   this Bundler will raise a warning during installation.

issues.title: (PUP-4039) - Improve yum provider handling of new package names
issues.body:
The yum provider will fail to find new package names due to `yum list` not refreshing metadata. #2654 caused this regression, but also implemented a much needed fix.

This change keeps the fix provided by #2654 and fixes new package name issue without extra manifest code. It also only causes extra steps to be taken when the initial `yum list` fails. Performance should not be impacted unless the package would otherwise fail.

Details available in [PUP-4039](https://tickets.puppetlabs.com/browse/PUP-4039).

issues.title: (PUP-6996) Add correct permissions to auto-generated production environment
issues.body:
When Puppet is run, it will create the production environment if it
is not already present.  If that run is done at the command line,
the resulting directory will be owned by root:root.  This is not
consistent with the ownership required by Code Manager and file
sync.

This patch corrects the permissions to be those set in the Puppet
configuration.  This prevents any possible permissions issues with
other Puppet components.

issues.title: (PUP-6637) New attribute :manage_mountpoint for Mount type
issues.body:
With this new feature, Puppet will be able to manage mountpoint directories prior to mounting or after unmounting without causing a multiple declaration error.

(WIP)
Questions:
1. Should the created mountpoint directory have 400 permissions, or is root:root ownership good enough?
2. How does the mount type behave if the parent directory or mountpoint do not exist? Is that being verified somewhere or do I need to implement some code for it?
3. What should be done if the mountpoint directory has contents after unmounting?
4. The provider spec tests have a name of `'/'` for all of the test resources. This doesn't really work for any tests I would write for this new attribute. What direction should I go in for that?

issues.title: (WIP)(PUP-6585) Deprecate Puppet::Util.absolute_path?
issues.body:
In an effort to validate some UTF-8 code paths (and their use of `absolute_path?`), I noticed that we have this method kicking around that Ruby already implements.

I also noticed that based on it's current implementation, it's being abused and allowing a lot of bad calls against it, since it doesn't verify the incoming object is a String / Pathname.  This is an effort to clean up all the errant calls as well, which are failing / succeeding for the wrong reasons when they pass in log objects, nil, floats, etc.

Need to understand https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppet/commit/94f5f53244eddb80bc4e8cb58859d12624b2daa9 more to see if we can really pull the existing method as it stands (it's the only call passing in `:posix` or `:windows`)

The original `absolute_path?` was only intended to accept path-like strings - see https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppet/commit/fb6df317016b8bbe44116e31ac5ededa4d1e0c75

But due to the fact that Ruby will regex compare any object, it's silently been the subject of torture over the years:

```
[1] pry(main)> o = Object.new
=> #<Object:0x007fea81b8f448>
[2] pry(main)> o =~ /foo/
=> nil
[3] pry(main)> !! (o =~ /foo/)
=> false
```

issues.title: (PUP-6531) improve service provider detection on Ubuntu
issues.body:
Rather than relying on version strings to determine which init-system is
in use, use the fact that the presence of /run/systemd/system (on
Debian-based systems generally, but I only can confirm for Ubuntu)
implies systemd is suitable.

Additionally, do not attempt to to use upstart in that case. However, if
systemd is not in use and upstart is the init-system (as detected by the
presence of the appropriate binaries as currently), treat upstart as
suitable.

Not-signed-off-by: Nishanth Aravamudan nish.aravamudan@canonical.com

issues.title: (PUP-6380) Fix HTTP file source for GET-only URIs
issues.body:
The Problem:
When using an HTTP URI as the source of a `file` type, URIs that only
work for GET requests fail.

The Use Case:
Pre-signed Amazon S3 URIs include the HTTP method in the signature,
which is usually GET for downloading files. This makes the URI return a
403 when responding to a HEAD request, but a 200 when responding to a
GET. Github uses Amazon S3 to store project 'releases', snapshots of a
repository at a certain release, usually prepackaged for different
operating systems and architectures.

The Code:
The `file` type fires off a HEAD request to the file's source when
trying to get metadata for the file,
https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppet/blob/master/lib/puppet/type/file/source.rb#L188.
Through the indirectors, this eventually makes its way to
Puppet::Util::HttpProxy, when a method of `:head`.

The Changes:
There are two main changes here, the first being that we now pass both
the `uri.path` and `uri.query` to HTTP requests. URI query parameters
can contain necessary authorization tokens or signatures, and many URIs
will fail without them. Once support for Ruby 1.9 is dropped, the entire
URI object can be passed into HTTP requests, rather than needed to
reconstruct the URI.

The second change is when a HEAD request fails, attempt a GET request
to see if that works. This should only happen in the file metadata case,
as this is the only case I could find that specifically uses the
HttpProxy class to make a HEAD request.

If there's a better way to do this/implement this or it's already being
taken care of, please let me know, as I'm still pretty new to this repo :)

Issue ticket: https://tickets.puppetlabs.com/browse/PUP-6380

commit.message:
(PUP-6274) Raise Error if included classname is undef or empty string

Before this, undef and empty string given to include would not lead to
an error because the Class[main] is known internally as '' which is also
what undef becomes in the 3.x API.

There is no legit case where the class '' should be allowed in the
puppet language.

This commit raises an error if include is given an empty string or
undef/nil.

commit.message:
(PUP-8297) Ensure we call SSLSocket#accept once

Previously, our webrick code set the webrick option SSLStartImmediately to true
and then called `SSLServer#start_immediately = false`, in that order. Ruby
versions 2.3.6/2.4.3 and up will skip the call to SSLSocket#accept if the
SSLStartImmediately option is false. However, older versions will skip the call
if the SSLServer `@start_immediately` instance variable is false[1].

Prior to commit a358d5ec0, newer ruby versions caused an error because
SSLSocket#accept was called twice on the same socket, once by webrick and again
by us.

Commit a358d5ec0 fixed the newer ruby case, but regressed on the older ruby
case, since SSLSocket#accept was never being called.

This commit eliminates the call to `start_immediately = false`, and sets the
configuration option to false. This works as far back as ruby 1.9.3, while
preserving the intent of the original issue[2].

Paired-with: Jacob Helwig <jacob@puppet.com>

[1] https://github.com/ruby/ruby/commit/2e728d51e70
[1] https://projects.puppetlabs.com/issues/2637
(packaging) Updating the puppet.pot file

commit.message:
(PUP-8357) Correctly match files for tasks

Previously, the existing_paths method for the FileBased loader was using
naive string matching to determine which files were associated with a
particular task. This resulted in the wrong set of files being found for
a task, in the case where the name of one task was a prefix of the name
of an adjacent task. For example, task `foo` would match both `foo.py`
and `foobar.py`. The desired behavior is that filenames need to match
all the way up to the file extension, in order to be associated with a
particular task.

This commit changes the existing_paths method to compare basenames
exactly, excluding file extensions.

commit.message:
(docs)(DOCUMENT-777)(PUP-8211) Clarify managehome.

Clarify when Puppet manages a user's home directory when the
`managehome` parameter is set to true.

(PUP-8343) Make rich data arguments to resources come through

Before this, the evaluator transformed all arguments to resources such
that some, but not all "rich data" was transformed to strings (notably
Regexp objects).
This was bad because a class, or define could then not rely on type
checking - a given Regexp would end up being a String which is
surprising because an error is expected.

The change in this commit is to not use the most aggressive 3x converter
for resources, and instead deal with rich data types in the
serialization (where it belongs).

The Serializer needed an update when turning a Regexp into a String, and
the output produced by Regexp#inspect is what puppet expects.

No tests are changed in the commit.

commit.message:
(PUP-8340) convert alias to use error_location

Convert the Catalog.alias() method to use the error_location()
for displaying the where the problem is

(PUP-8297) Don't accept already connected socket

Webrick's start method yields an already connected socket, so it is not
necessary to call accept on the socket. In ruby versions prior to 2.3.6 and
2.4.3, the accept call was a noop.

In 2.3.6 and 2.4.3, it is an error, because ruby those versions use a
non-blocking accept to handle clients that make an TCP connection, but
are slow to negotiate the TLS handshake[1,2]. On these versions, puppet
master would report:

    SSL_accept returned=1 errno=0 state=unknown state: unexpected record

Remove the call to Socket#accept.

[1] https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/14005
[2] https://github.com/ruby/ruby/commit/2e728d51e70ed3756ad760c687a08b8487b0112f

commit.message:
(PUP-4963) Puppet module build fails on FIPS enabled system

We now disallow the module tool operations of build, install, uninstall, and upgrade.
This is done to be able to provide an appropriate error message gracefully instead
of the operations getting aborted due to FIPS prohibiting use of any
unapproved algorithms like MD5 that above module operations use.
Module tool's use of MD5 checksums cannot be changed easily without requiring a
large number of design changes throughout.

(PUP-8082) Fix incorrect field padding in colorized PMT search results

Since the PMT search output uses printf to pad the results into
consistent width columns, we need to insert the color modifying control
sequences only AFTER the widths and padding have been calculated,
otherwise the padding calculations will be incorrect when the terminal
interprets the control sequences.

(docs) Outdated links on README.md

Filed Ticket indicating 2 outdated links.
Updated those links.

Also:
* beautified some of the sentences, adding commas for improved readability.
* shortened a few instances of the hyperlinked text.
* fixed casing on a few phrases.

commit.message:
(PUP-8342) Update report serialization/deserialization, schema, and schema version to include transaction_completed

This update adds transaction_completed to report serialization/deserialization, and schema, and updates the schema version.
(PUP-7397) Use group metadata with hash to only skip specific tests

(PUP-7397) Atomically update filebucket contents files

Using replace_file instead of Puppet::FileSystem::open ensures we'll never have
a partially written content in a contents file.

replace_file more properly handles permissions on windows, which means we
create contents files that are actually read-only. As such, we cannot touch
them to update the mtime if someone uploads the same content again.

Marked tests pending wherever possible for LFN issue on windows, but did have to mark one test as 'skip'. Until PUP-8257 is resolved.

(PUP-7394) Change behavior of replace_file to change file mode after yield

Previously, when replacing an existing file, replace_file would set the temp
file's permissions to be that of the existing file or the provided default
permissions before yielding to the block. This was done originally because the
temp file was created with insecure file permissions. This is no longer
necessary, because Puppet::FileSystem::Uniquefile creates temporary files with
mode 0600.

The previous behavior of using the existing file's mode before yielding to the
block meant that we couldn't write to the temporary file if the file we were
trying to replace was read-only. By setting the final permissions of the file
after yielding to the block we no longer run into this issue.

commit.message:
(PUP-8285) Check if file exists using the configured bucket

Previously, if you used a non-default bucket directory, the backup
command would only backup the file if it didn't exist in the default
bucket. This was a result of not passing the `bucket_path` request
option in the call to `Puppet::FileBucket::File.indirection.head`.

The same change is not need when calling `save` because in that case we
have an instance of Puppet::FileBucket::File that we want to save, and
it is already configured with the correct bucket_path.

(maint) Remove unnecessary binary json test

This test was attempting to verify that the json terminus would error
in the face of files on disk with binary names. It doesn't actually do
that, and is also broken on High Sierra with APFS

Since this is not a particular valuable thing to test, instead of
attempting to repair the test it is simply being removed.

commit.message:
(pup-8288) Report exceptions during transactions as failed status.

Without this patch, exceptions during a transaction that are not caught will not be marked as failed.

Users and tools that use exit status information are not catching these failures due to the incorrect information.

This patch creates a flag that must be positively changed at the end of the transaction flow to allow the transaction to be marked with success.

(PUP-8127) change the error location output to be translatable

Created a common method for making a string of the the location of an error
Changed the error reporting and logging systems to use the common methods
Updated all the unit tests
Updated acceptance test

(PUP-8066) Updated set of acceptance tests for fips compliance

These tests detect fips mode using "fips_enabled" fact to allow
them to execute on both fips and non-fips platforms.

Updated versions of acceptance tests to run in FIPS mode:
 - acceptance/tests/face/loadable_from_modules.rb
 - acceptance/tests/modules/build/build_agent.rb
 - acceptance/tests/modules/build/build_should_not_create_changes.rb
 - acceptance/tests/modules/install/basic_install.rb
 - acceptance/tests/modules/install/with_version.rb
 - acceptance/tests/parser_functions/calling_all_functions.rb
 - acceptance/tests/puppet_apply_a_file_should_create_a_file_and_report_the_md5.rb
 - acceptance/tests/resource/file/content_attribute.rb
 - acceptance/tests/resource/file/source_attribute.rb
 - acceptance/tests/ticket_1334_clientbucket_corrupted.rb
 - acceptance/tests/ticket_3961_puppet_ca_should_produce_certs.rb
 - acceptance/tests/ticket_4622_filebucket_diff_test.rb
 - acceptance/tests/ticket_6541_invalid_filebucket_files.rb

(PUP-8122) Change sentence fragment to This depends on ...

Change the sentence fragment for listing the dependency cycle errors
from "which depends on" to "This depends on"
Fixed creation of the dependency list so that that don't overwrite
the specificied version line

(MAINT) Remove Travis before_install step

Prior to this commit the Travis config included a `before_install`
step, added in https://tickets.puppetlabs.com/browse/PUP-7920,
which installed bundler at `1.15.4` to workaround
https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/8357, which is fixed.

We discovered during research for MODULES-6339 that Travis now keeps
their matrices updated with the latest compatible bundler install.

For all of the builds in this matrix Travis is currently using
bundler `1.16.0` and the builds pass successfully.

This maintenance commit removes the pinned-version install of
bundler and instead returns to relying on Travis to build and
maintain images with compatible versions. This also follows the
advice in the comment in the config file on this step.

commit.message:
(PUP-8259) Make loader discovery report errors instead of failing

Before this commit, a function, type, plan, or task declaration that
contained errors would cause the loader discovery to raise an exception.
This is now changed so that the discovery will either raise warnings or
collect errors in an `error_collector` array that can be passed as an
optional argument. If the `error_collector` is provided, errors will not
be logged but instead converted into `Puppet::DataType::Error` instances
and added to the collector.

Revert "(PUP-8262) Revert changes which made non-existent SMF services return"

This reverts commit 516595760379def5aa14140e1cca71d0db8e8a71.

commit.message:
(PUP-7482) Eliminate redundant HEAD request

Previously, request_with_redirects would make two HEAD requests when
passed :head as the method, which happens when retrieving file metadata
for http-based file sources.

If the first HEAD request succeeds and isn't a redirect, then just
return that response.

(PUP-7482) Accept all content types with http file sources

In commit 89ea46b610, we modified puppet to use proper mime types in the
HTTP Accept header instead of the Puppet::Network::Format name. However,
we missed the case when using a file resource with http/https source
parameter, because the corresponding file_metadata and file_content
termini create Net::HTTP connections directly.

This commit makes puppet send "Accept: */*" for http/https file sources.
This is preferred over application/octet-stream, because some webservers
like Apache and IIS will respond with HTTP 406 if we request
octet-stream, but the file extension maps to some other well-known MIME
type, e.g. image/gif.

We also send "Accept-Encoding" so the server can send us compressed
content, and we set "User-Agent" based on the puppet version, like we do
for other HTTP connections.

This commit changes behavior in two ways. First, we send the above
headers when making the HEAD request prior to sending the "real"
request. And we send the above headers when a block is not given.
(packaging) Updating the puppet.pot file

commit.message:
(docs) Reword description to clarify truncated text

If you read the docs page describing the user resource, the summary for
the `expiry` parameter says `The expiry date for this user. Must be
provided...`, which might lead a user to believe that the parameter is
required.

This rewords the description so that the truncated version is clearly
not implying a required parameter.

I think there's a high chance that PUP-7663 originated as the user
mistakingly believing that they had to provide a value. (it's also
possible that they've specified defaults in `login.defs` and are trying
to override it for a specific user account.)

(PUP-8270) Skip range max when presenting types with max == default

Several data types have a string representation that includes a range
with min and max values. Such representations will always come last in
an array. When creating type with a range from parameters, it's standard
that when the 'max' parameter is omitted it gets the default (unbounded)
value. This commit ensures that a 'max' with default value also is
omitted when the type is represented as a string. E.g. an integer
created as `Integer[2]` will presented as 'Integer[2]' instead of
'Integer[2, default]'.

commit.message:
(PUP-8271) Make loader discovery find 'init' for plans and tasks

Before this commit, the discovery mechanism would incorrectly consider a
file named plans/init.pp to denote a plan named `<module-name>::init`.
The same thing was true files under tasks with names starting with
'init'.

This commit ensures that the `SmartPath` used for Plans and Tasks is
aware of the 'init' semantics when producing the `TypedName` for the
actual Plan or Target, thus avoiding errors about a name mismatch when
the corresponding entity is loaded.

commit.message:
Merge branch 'jcpunk-PUP-7685'

* commit '22312fd8d':
  (PUP-7685) Remove duplicate entries when listing user resource's groups

(PUP-8269) Move handling of future reserved word 'plan' to validator

Before this commit, the parser would emit a `Model::ReservedWord` with
future == true for the word `plan` when --tasks was not used. This led
to problems in the evaluator because it was not equipped to handle
reserved words that were allowed.

This commit changes the parser so that it no longer has special handling
of the word 'plan' (unless --tasks is used) and the responsibility of
issuing a warnning that a future reserved word is used is moved to the
validator `Checker4_0`.

The commit also removes the 'application', 'produces' and 'consumes'
from the hash of `FUTURE_RESERVED_WORDS` since they are now keywords.

commit.message: (PUP-8195) Add test asserting definition of a data type in top namespace

(PUP-8195) Search module for ruby defined data types in top namespace

This commit ensures that a search is made in the top namespace for types
declared using the `Puppet::Datatypes#create_type`.
(PUP-8195) Add test using ruby data type defined in a module.

(PUP-8195) Add ability to load Ruby code using the autoloader

This commit adds the method `load_file` to the DSL used by
`Puppet::Datatypes::create_type`. The `load_file` will dispatch the
call to `Puppet::Util::Autoload#load_file` to allow files to be loaded
from the current environment and its modules.

(maint) Remove AppVeyor OpenSSL update

 - The fix in place here was temporary due to AppVeyor having available
   an older Ruby 2.4.x that shipped a buggy OpenSSL 2.0.3 with a race
   condition. Without the upgrade to at least OpenSSL 2.0.4, installing
   large gemsets would intermittently fail.

   * Original RubyInstaller discussion at:
   https://github.com/oneclick/rubyinstaller2/issues/68

   * Ruby bug is documented at https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/11033

   * OpenSSL 2.0.4 contains the patch as of 8/8/2017
   https://github.com/ruby/ruby/commit/b08e0ade5baacbc7d4754e9f6afe8d09a3e00bc5#diff-51a5e2412fcf851e37d1883b1ae53de5

   * RubyInstaller 2.4.2-2 picked up the fix and was released 9/15/2017
   https://rubyinstaller.org/2017/09/15/rubyinstaller-2.4.2-2-released.html

   * AppVeyor issue was filed
   https://github.com/appveyor/ci/issues/1790

   AppVeyor began shipping updated Ruby in their 11/18/2017 release:
   https://github.com/appveyor/ci/issues/1892
   https://www.appveyor.com/updates/
(maint) Remove useless assignment causing rubucop error.

commit.message: (maint)(PUP-5206) Update spec test so it fails on code before 173b5780
(packaging) Updating the puppet.pot file

(PUP-8244) Enable Lint/UselessAssignment rubocop

Enable rubocop check and update remaining issues.

(PUP-8244) Removed unused code

Remove code related to Lint/UselessAssignments.

(PUP-8244) Call the accessor instead of assigning to local variable

Previously we were trying to call accessor methods, but ruby will
instead create a local variable that shadows the setter[1]:

    When using method assignment you must always have a receiver. If you do
    not have a receiver Ruby assumes you are assigning to a local variable.

Puppet::Resource removes the call because the environment attribute is
invoked in the attributes.each block below. Note in the case that an
environment attribute doesn't exist, we never call
`send('environment=')`. However that is consistent behavior with what
happened previously, since `environment = nil` was a noop.

Puppet::Resource::Status removes the line, because the `failed` instance
variable is already set when adding the event with a `failure` status.

[1] https://docs.ruby-lang.org/en/2.0.0/syntax/assignment_rdoc.html

(PUP-8244) Preserve current mode when reaching end of input

Remove the line that tried to switch the mode when reaching end of
input. The line didn't do anything because it was setting the value of a
local variable instead of calling the accessor.

commit.message:
(PUP-8262) Revert changes which made non-existent SMF services return
:absent instead of :stopped

Prior to Puppet 4.10.9, non-existent Solaris SMF services reported their
state as :stopped, and could be defined as :stopped in Puppet code, to
ensure that unwanted services were not running, even if they were not
installed. In Puppet 4.10.9, this behavior was changed to cause
non-existent Solaris SMF services to report a state of :absent. This
change was too intrusive for our LTS branch and has caused workflow and
upgrade problems for users.

This commit consolidates the following reverts:

    Revert "(PUP-6797) service should check for smf service first"
    This reverts commit 3d7a3c4c1c6697047ae356c8765928f68618bc69.

    Revert "(PUP-6860) puppet on solaris 11 should support exists? for
services"
    This reverts commit dd30a54c9ff5fba9f980147b4a7af80442e009ed.

    Revert "(PUP-6797) service should check for smf service first"
    This reverts commit 3d7a3c4c1c6697047ae356c8765928f68618bc69.

    Revert "(PUP-6797) Update SMF tests for nonexistent service"
    This reverts commit 7085af0b7e508d86caa9e30bf44bed931d65f0df.

    Revert "(maint) (PUP-6767) remove redundant smf acceptance testing"
    This reverts commit b539fe581f372514e28f4c7e095d81dc8b0f500c.

    Revert "(PUP-8167) SMF provider: do not try to stop :absent
services"
    This reverts commit 7183a352288867392c1c934270c494e7b1270ab0.

commit.message:
(DOCS) Update error message

When a user runs Puppet not as root, the error message starts them
down a certificate rabbit hole. This commit adds a friendly reminder and
the tests associated with it.

(PUP-8248) Fix service enable acceptance test for Amazon Linux

amazon linux is based on el: 2017.09 and earlier is based on el-6 (sysV)
and 2017.12 and later is based on el-7 (systemd). In beaker we still use
the el platform name, so rely on facter checks when filtering which os
versions use sysV vs. systemd for the tests.

(PUP-8248) Confine upstart provider to Amazon Linux < 2017.12

Since we confine upstart to el-6 but not el-7, likewise confine it to
Amazon Linux < 2017.12, the versions based on el-6.
(PUP-8248) Make systemd the default provider for Amazon Linux 2017.12

(PUP-8195) Move Target to datatypes directory

This commit changes the `Target` into a plain ruby class and
moves the declaration and implementation to the puppet/datatypes
directory.

Note! This is the first step in moving the type into Bolt.

(PUP-8195) Move ExecutionResult to datatypes directory

This commit changes the `ExecutionResult` into a plain ruby class and
moves the declaration and implementation to the puppet/datatypes
directory.

Note! This is the first step in moving the type into Bolt.

(PUP-8195) Move Error data type to datatypes directory

This commit moves the Error data type to the datatypes directory. It
also adds a plain ruby class for the Error so that it can be used
without a configured type system (i.e. outside of compiler scope).
(PUP-8195) Add tests for Puppet::DataTypes

(PUP-8195) Make TypeFormatter format plain ruby objects correctly

Prior to this commit, the TypeFormatter would not recognize a plain
ruby object that was mapped to a data type. This commit adds a the
method `string_Object` to capture this where a proper infer of the
instance is made. The output is then based on the inferred type.

(PUP-8195) Make it possible to pass element type when creating Iterator

This commit makes it possible to pass an element type when creating
an iterator for an Array och a Hash. Prior to this commit, such element
types had to be inferred which is an unnecessary step when the element
type is already known.

(PUP-8195) Fix inference of plain ruby objecs and parameterized type

Prior to this commit, only implementations that included the
`PuppetObject` module could infer a parameterized type from the values
of the attributes in the instance. This commit ensures that plain ruby
objects that are mapped to a data type are infered such that the
type is correctly parametereized.

(PUP-8195) Ensure that StringConverter recognizes PObjectTypeExtension

The StringConverter when passed an instance of a parameterized object
type, did not recognize the instance of an Object data type and produce
incorrect output. This commit ensures that the PObjectTypeExtension
is recognized.

(PUP-8195) Minor speed improvement and bug-fix in serialization

This commit ensures that the `parameter_info` generated by the
`PObjectType` is cached since it is called on from many places. A minor
speed improvement/bug fix is also made to the deserializer where the
reader no longer needs to obtain the type of instance that it reads.
This also fixes a problem with reading plain ruby objects that are
mapped to data types. Before this commit, the reader would assume that
the class always had a _pcore_type method.
(PUP-8195) Make Object a RichDataType instead of Error

(PUP-8195) Add ability to pre-load dynamically defined data types

This commit adds a `pre_load` method to the `Loaders` instance and
ensures that it is called once the loader framework has been fully
configured. The intention is to add pre-loading of dynamically defined
types that can be found by the puppet system loader.

(PUP-8195) Fix glitch causing data-typed plain objects to fail on []

The evaluator would fail to call the underlying method for an data type
with a '[]' function declared when the mapped type was aa plain ruby
object. This is because the evaluator tested for the PuppetObject module
which a plain ruby object doesn't include.

This commit ensures that the type is inferred using the `TypeCalculator`
which in turn will consult the `ImplementationRegistry` if needed.

(PUP-8195) Fix glitch preventing proper serialization of Type[Callable]

The Object interface for the Callable type had incorrect definitions for
the attributes 'param_types' and 'block_type'. This made it impossible
to serialize a Callable type.

(PUP-8195) Add ability to register data type with Ruby implementation

This commit adds `Puppet::DataTypes#create_type`. It allows the user
to create new data types in Ruby in a way similar to how a function can
be created using `Puppet::Functions#create_function`.

In addition to the new `Puppet::DataType` module, this commit also adds
a `RubyDataTypeInstantiator` and `DataTypePath` to the loader framework
and the new loadable `:datatype`.

(PUP-7861) Update git mirror instructions

Prior to this commit, we were referencing an incorrect environment
variable to specify if the user wanted to hit a specific git mirror. In
Beaker, the environment variable we look for is either SERVER or
PROJECT_NAME_SERVER (i.e., PUPPET_SERVER). This commit updates
acceptance/README.md to accurately reflect this.

(PUP-7861) Update git mirror instructions

Prior to this commit, we were referencing an incorrect environment
variable to specify if the user wanted to hit a specific git mirror. In
Beaker, the environment variable we look for is either SERVER or
PROJECT_NAME_SERVER (i.e., PUPPET_SERVER). This commit updates
acceptance/README.md to accurately reflect this.

commit.message:
(PUP-8237) Make Puppet::Pal::ScriptCompiler available to functions

This commit makes the `Puppet::Pal::ScriptCompiler` available using a
`Puppet::Context` override. The compiler is available using the symbol
`:pal_script_compiler`.

A new special parameter type named `script_compiler_param` is also added
to the Ruby function dispatcher builder for `InternalFunction`. Usage is
similar to `scope_param` but it injects the script compiler instead of
injecting the scope.

(PUP-8237) Simplify function parameter injection

This commit removes some obsolete logic that was designed to handle
injection performed by the advanced but not really used injection system
that was earlier removed from Puppet core.

In essence, instead of passing a four element array with various data
about the injection, only a symbol denoting the parameter to be injected
is passed on. Dead code in the form of the two methods `injected_param`
and `injected_producer_param` is removed.

pull_requests.title: (PUP-3802) Fix yaourt on Arch linux.
(PUP-8337) Change Windows symlink? check behavior
pull_requests.body:
- Previously, any file that returned FILE_ATTRIBUTE_REPARSE_POINT
   in a call to GetFileAttributes would be considered a "symlink" for
   Puppets purpose. This is relevant specifically to file resources.

   However, Puppet cannot resolve the destination location for many of
   the reparse point types, namely the following (some of which may
   not actually resolve to a different path):

   IO_REPARSE_TAG_HSM
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_HSM2
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_SIS
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_WIM
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_CSV
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_DFS
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_DFSR
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_DEDUP
   IO_REPARSE_TAG_NFS

 - Modify the behavior of symlink? such that Puppet only considers
   reparse points IO_REPARSE_TAG_MOUNT_POINT, IO_REPARSE_TAG_SYMLINK
   as resolvable symlinks.

   The others will continue to be treated as regular files /
   directories.

 - Existing symlink? behavior has been factored out to a reparse_point?
   method responsible for only validating the file attribute contains
   the reparse attribute.

 - This introduces some additional work once a path is determined as a
   reparse point, but this should not happen regularly as reparse
   points are typically fairly rare on Windows systems.

 - Change the behavior of exist? to function similarly to symlink? in that
   only understandable symlinks will be followed. exist? will return true
   for reparse points that are not mount or symlink reparse points

pull_requests.title: (maint) Allow numeric hostnames in hiera_in_templates test
pull_requests.body:
This test creates a hash of hostname -> directory, and stores it in
YAML for hiera to query. If the hostname happens to be purely numeric,
the key in the hash will be a number, rather than a string. Facter
always returns the `hostname` fact as a string. This causes the hash
lookup in the puppet code to fail, and the manifest to fail to
compile.

The fix is to prepend a bit of non-numeric junk to the hostname, so
that the key in hiera is always string.

pull_requests.title: (PUP-8223) Improve user and group forcelocal support
(PUP-8114) Make enabled state check accurate for SLES 11 boot services in redhat service provider
pull_requests.body:
(PUP-8114) Make enabled state check accurate for SLES 11 boot services in redhat service provider

Without this patch applied, the redhat service provider is not idempotent
in enabling SLES 11 boot services. These are special Sys V services beginning
with the string 'boot.'. When `chkconfig` is run against them, they print
'<name>  B' instead of '<name>  on', so the existing regex does not match them.
Thus the redhat provider always sees them as disabled, and tries to enable
them on each agent run.

This patch adds the '<name>  B' condition to the regex.

```
$ chkconfig boot.kdump
boot.kdump  B
```

Before:
```
$ puppet agent -t --debug 2>&1 | grep -i kdump | grep -i enable
Notice: /Stage[main]/Kdump/Service[kdump]/enable: enable changed 'false' to 'true'
```

After: 
```
$ puppet agent -t --debug 2>&1 | grep -i kdump | grep -i enable
```

pull_requests.title: (WIP) ci:test:git for SLES11
(PUP-7648) Fix ci:test:git pre-suite on OSX 10.11
pull_requests.body:
- A number of problems prevented ci:test:git from executing properly
   on OSX 10.11:

   * When performing a `gem install bundler`, system Ruby places the
     binstub in /usr/local/bin. However, the SSH environment is not
     configured with /usr/local/bin in PATH. There are multiple
     solutions to this problem:

      - Add /usr/local/bin to ~/.ssh/environment in Beaker - covered
        in BKR-1139. This allows any additional binaries that might
        be installed (homebrew, git, other Ruby gems with binstubs
        such as puppet and facter) to be available. This is the most
        effective universal solution but requires a Beaker release.

        A workaround is in place to do this in 000_EnvSetup of the
        pre-suite until Beaker changes land.

      - Add to the host[:host_env] hash of environment variables via
        a Beaker options file, so that PATH is augmented with
        /usr/local/bin. Unfortunately this requires setting additional
        hosts / options files on disk prior to any code running in
        the Puppet pre-suite, to be picked up during Beakers host
        initialization and injected into ~/.ssh/environment correctly.
        Otherwise, the PATH would have to be manipulated in each new
        SSH command. Due to beaker-hostgenerator commonly being used
        to execute, its simpler to avoid this option.

        Note that beaker-hostgenerator should also allow arbitrary
        settings injection using {} syntax, but this doesn't appear to
        work properly with ci:test:git and it's uncertain if it
        properly handles the :host_env hash when writing to YAML.

   * When performing `bundle install`, ensure Ruby is configured to
     use OSX platform specific gems where possible. This impacts
     the inclusion of CFPropertyList.

   * Due to OSX SIP (System Integrity Protection) /usr/bin is not
     writable and /usr/local/bin should be used instead. Override
     Beakers default puppetbindir setting to /usr/local/bin and use
     that as the --binstub directory when installing the Puppet source
     with Bundler. binstubs should continue to use /usr/bin/ruby as
     the interpreter.

   * Similarly, when calling install.rb, provide --bindir as the same
     /usr/local/bin as the system Ruby binstub dir is not otherwise
     writable. Beaker helpers will fully qualify the path to puppet
     using the puppetbindir setting already.

pull_requests.title: (PUP-7519) Enabling rubocop securitycop scans
pull_requests.body:
Background: Rubocop scans were not running as the various cops in .rubocop.yml were not kept uptodate with the latest definitions. This will enable only SecurityCop/YAMLLoad as a start to revive the scans in an effort to flag any inadvertent usages.  Additional security or other cop rules can/would be added in future.   
Rubocop do not have support for flagging YAML.load_file which would have been desirable. Likewise it is not necessary to mark the known instance of Yaml.load_file in Puppet::Util::Yaml to be ignored.

Note that there are a couple of other YAML.load instances elsewhere so this may generate violations. If that is not desired this PR be merged after all these have been resolved/changed appropriately.

pull_requests.title: (PUP-6134) Explicitly locate gemcmd windows
pull_requests.body:
On Windows:

Puppet is unable to install a ruby gem anywhere other than Puppet's ruby.
Caused by Puppet prepending its paths (including our gem) to PATH.
This fix removes Puppet's paths from PATH when setting :gemcmd.

(A larger-scale solution would involve a path/target parameter to Package.)

pull_requests.title: (DO NOT MERGE)(maint) Set BUNDLE_SPECIFIC_PLATFORM=true
pull_requests.body:
**This might be one to outright close, but note that without it we're not using platform-specific Facter which depends on CFPropertyList**

 - Bundler, under some circumstances, may not install platform-specific
   gems.  For instance, using a bundle install of the Puppet Gemfile
   will not install the universal-darwin version of Facter.

 - Set the environment variable BUNDLE_SPECIFIC_PLATFORM also
   had to be set to properly use platform-specific versions of any
   gems that have been referenced.  This will be the default behavior
   in Bundler 2, and given platform-specific versions of Facter are
   shipped - should always be the case for Puppet. Without setting
   this Bundler will raise a warning during installation.

pull_requests.title: (PUP-6996) Add correct permissions to auto-generated production environment
pull_requests.body:
When Puppet is run, it will create the production environment if it
is not already present.  If that run is done at the command line,
the resulting directory will be owned by root:root.  This is not
consistent with the ownership required by Code Manager and file
sync.

This patch corrects the permissions to be those set in the Puppet
configuration.  This prevents any possible permissions issues with
other Puppet components.

pull_requests.body:
With this new feature, Puppet will be able to manage mountpoint directories prior to mounting or after unmounting without causing a multiple declaration error.

(WIP)
Questions:
1. Should the created mountpoint directory have 400 permissions, or is root:root ownership good enough?
2. How does the mount type behave if the parent directory or mountpoint do not exist? Is that being verified somewhere or do I need to implement some code for it?
3. What should be done if the mountpoint directory has contents after unmounting?
4. The provider spec tests have a name of `'/'` for all of the test resources. This doesn't really work for any tests I would write for this new attribute. What direction should I go in for that?

pull_requests.title: (WIP)(PUP-6585) Deprecate Puppet::Util.absolute_path?
pull_requests.body:
In an effort to validate some UTF-8 code paths (and their use of `absolute_path?`), I noticed that we have this method kicking around that Ruby already implements.

I also noticed that based on it's current implementation, it's being abused and allowing a lot of bad calls against it, since it doesn't verify the incoming object is a String / Pathname.  This is an effort to clean up all the errant calls as well, which are failing / succeeding for the wrong reasons when they pass in log objects, nil, floats, etc.

Need to understand https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppet/commit/94f5f53244eddb80bc4e8cb58859d12624b2daa9 more to see if we can really pull the existing method as it stands (it's the only call passing in `:posix` or `:windows`)

The original `absolute_path?` was only intended to accept path-like strings - see https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppet/commit/fb6df317016b8bbe44116e31ac5ededa4d1e0c75

But due to the fact that Ruby will regex compare any object, it's silently been the subject of torture over the years:

```
[1] pry(main)> o = Object.new
=> #<Object:0x007fea81b8f448>
[2] pry(main)> o =~ /foo/
=> nil
[3] pry(main)> !! (o =~ /foo/)
=> false
```

pull_requests.title: (PUP-6531) improve service provider detection on Ubuntu
pull_requests.body:
Rather than relying on version strings to determine which init-system is
in use, use the fact that the presence of /run/systemd/system (on
Debian-based systems generally, but I only can confirm for Ubuntu)
implies systemd is suitable.

Additionally, do not attempt to to use upstart in that case. However, if
systemd is not in use and upstart is the init-system (as detected by the
presence of the appropriate binaries as currently), treat upstart as
suitable.

Not-signed-off-by: Nishanth Aravamudan nish.aravamudan@canonical.com

pull_requests.title: (PUP-6380) Fix HTTP file source for GET-only URIs
pull_requests.body:
The Problem:
When using an HTTP URI as the source of a `file` type, URIs that only
work for GET requests fail.

The Use Case:
Pre-signed Amazon S3 URIs include the HTTP method in the signature,
which is usually GET for downloading files. This makes the URI return a
403 when responding to a HEAD request, but a 200 when responding to a
GET. Github uses Amazon S3 to store project 'releases', snapshots of a
repository at a certain release, usually prepackaged for different
operating systems and architectures.

The Code:
The `file` type fires off a HEAD request to the file's source when
trying to get metadata for the file,
https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppet/blob/master/lib/puppet/type/file/source.rb#L188.
Through the indirectors, this eventually makes its way to
Puppet::Util::HttpProxy, when a method of `:head`.

The Changes:
There are two main changes here, the first being that we now pass both
the `uri.path` and `uri.query` to HTTP requests. URI query parameters
can contain necessary authorization tokens or signatures, and many URIs
will fail without them. Once support for Ruby 1.9 is dropped, the entire
URI object can be passed into HTTP requests, rather than needed to
reconstruct the URI.

The second change is when a HEAD request fails, attempt a GET request
to see if that works. This should only happen in the file metadata case,
as this is the only case I could find that specifically uses the
HttpProxy class to make a HEAD request.

If there's a better way to do this/implement this or it's already being
taken care of, please let me know, as I'm still pretty new to this repo :)

Issue ticket: https://tickets.puppetlabs.com/browse/PUP-6380

Puppet apply can be used for any number of things, including one-shot modifications to a system.  Dropping all the data from regular runs just because someone ran something through it seems risky: your database server would stop being a database server until the next full run, which is probably not what you want.

I am pretty sure this is an unresolvable problem, because we have a single piece of data (classes.txt) that is trying to represent something much more dynamic, the set of applicable classes (or, perhaps, successfully applied classes) of the machine at a point in time.

Making this optional, or writing to a separate file, would be much more acceptable.

You can configure this for apply/agent, perhaps we need an [apply] section:

[main]
  classfile = $vardir/state/apply_classes.txt

[agent]
  classfile = $vardir/state/classes.txt

I agree this should be clearly spelled out in release documentation.

Daniel,

I'm in agreement with Nan.

We do make claims that puppet apply is a "first class citizen" and community members like Jordan Sissel heavily rely on puppet apply being feature complete with puppet agent.

Furthermore, puppet apply is more suitable for situations like Vagrant where a full master is not avaialable or necessary.

Finally, as we integrate more with MCollective, the classes.txt file becomes ever more important for filtering.

For these reasons I think we should still write the file and we should write it to the same file the agent writes to by default.

If the end user desires, we support writing to multiple files as Nan illustrated above.

I'll re-open this once.  If you still disagree, please feel free to close the pull request and I won't re-open it.

You mentioned being new to Git, GitHub & Ruby, so please forgive me if you already know what follows.

You should be able to "uncommit" the commit you have on this branch by checking it out, and doing `git reset HEAD~`.  This brings you to a state as though you had made the changes on disk, but hadn't yet committed them.

You should then be able to make any additional changes (adding tests, calling `execute` directly, etc.).

After that, you can add bits, and pieces of the individual files to the staging area to split them out into separate commits by using `git add --interactive`.  [Pro Git's section on "Interactive Staging"](http://progit.org/book/ch6-2.html) has some decent documentation about how to do this, specifically the "Staging Patches" section.

Hope this helps.

Regarding the fix for (#8374) and jhelwig's comments on the original pull request:

The command 
  execute([:port, "-q", :info, "--line", "--version", "--revision", @resource[:name]], :combine => false)
will not use the "port" command defined at the beginning of the class, but just execute "port" and assume it's on the PATH.

What is the right way to fix this?

There are a number of tests that are known to fail on Windows due to things like missing support in types/providers.  If you run the tests by doing something like `rspec --tag ~fails_on_windows spec`, then you'll only be running the tests that should actually have all the support necessary to run.  Eventually the `fails_on_windows` tag will go away, but for now, it's marking the areas where we know Puppet does not work correctly on Windows, but should before we can call the initial Windows support "done".
Rather than specifying `:port` as the first argument in the array, you'd need to use `"/opt/local/bin/port"`.

Good commit. I ran through the big changes and tried to break it, but couldn't find any obvious weaknesses. Good test coverage, as well. However, by setting group ownership to one in which the user is not a member, you can get into a state where it is impossible to recover. For example, it became impossible for the MSI installer (which runs as SYSTEM) to read or update a package (I had to manually take ownership, and reset permissions to recover). When trying to change the owner/group properties on a large file tree (Apache, for instance), it took a very long time (over 10 minutes on on WS2008).

+
+    def sid_for_account(name)
+      sid = nil
+      if name =~ /\\/
+        domain, name = name.split('\\', 2)
+        query = "SELECT Sid from Win32_Account WHERE Name = '#{name}' AND Domain = '#{domain}' AND LocalAccount = true"
+      else
+        query = "SELECT Sid from Win32_Account WHERE Name = '#{name}' AND LocalAccount = true"
+      end
+      execquery(query).each { |u| sid ||= u.Sid }
+      sid
+    end

   end

Just below where the new `ensure_running_as_root` function is called, the script checks to see if it is running as root, warning and exiting appropriately if it isn't.

The original behavior of warn & exit rather than invoking sudo seems much more well behaved to me, compared to automatically calling sudo if it's not root.  Typically with root privileges it is the responsibility of the user to provide them to the script that needs them rather than for the script to take them for itself (at least in my experience).

I'm leaning towards not making this particular change based on how I'd expect it to behave from most other "root required" scripts, and that it already warns & exits rather than blowing up if not run as root.

@soh, do you have any thoughts?  UX is definitely one of your hot-spot areas.

I agree with Jacob.  I understand the motivation behind this change, but I think it's unexpected behavior for a script to assume root privileges without notification or confirmation.  The simple and common notify/confirm behavior is as Jacob describes:  warn & exit, and allow the user to `sudo !!`.
I'm closing the pull request since this would cause `createpackage.sh` to break from common & generally expected behavior for a script that requires root permissions.

I would also expect the behavior to be to remove any principal  mentioned, but it doesn't seem like a change that should be made in a point release.  I'd be a lot more comfortable if it were changed to warn in 2.7.x and moved to the new behavior in a future version, especially since this affects all types with `:array_matching => :all` (including custom types written by users of Puppet).

> This patch improves the usability of the `puppet apply` command by
> adding a new `--catalog` option. This patch also adds a deprecation
> warning whenever the `--apply` option is used, which advises end-users
> to use the `--catalog` option instead.
> 
> This patch updates the in-line help documentation by adding help output
> for the new `--catalog` option, and adding a deprecation warning for the
> `--apply` option.
> 
> The plan is to deprecate the `--apply` option in the next 2.7.x release,
> and removal in 2.8. External documentation should be updated to reflect
> the new preference towards using the `--catalog` option in-place of
> `--apply`.

Especially now I'm running into some headaches with puppet device, I think it would be better to have a more consistent options across the board (we should support classes.txt for devices as well). 

Since anything else other than [agent] [main] [master] is considered an environment in puppet.conf. > This seems to be getting somewhat messy. I don't know if we should add an option that's applicable only to apply and not agent. If we intend to add this option I think it makes sense to have this available across the board. Especially now I'm running into some headaches with puppet device, I think it would be better to have a more consistent options across the board (we should support classes.txt for devices as well).

Keep in mind that the device proxy will usually run on the same system as a real agent; we are clearly in a world where we want to expose this information to users somehow, and where we need multiple instances on a single machine.  Just `classes.txt` isn't cutting it any more in this new world.

So, how does this actually get rid of the missing sequence error?  The ticket mentions `This is due to setting of “:id => false” in puppet/lib/puppet/rails/database/schema.rb`, but neither the ticket, nor the commit message actually say why this is a problem, and how removing it fixes things.

Since :id => false, the sequence table is not created when one tries to enable inventory, id column is created perfectly fine though. Removing :=>false creates the sequence table and hence get rid of missing sequence table error.

Hi Cody, Although the report will be sent via HTTPS, the agent will not verify the server's SSL cert and so can be spoofed. I think we want to get an HTTP connection from Puppet::Network::HttpPool.http_instance(host, port), which will setup the trusted certs.

On Tue, Nov 29, 2011 at 11:00, Josh Cooper
reply@reply.github.com
wrote:

> Prior to #2848 (CVE-2011-3872), if Puppet[:certdnsnames] was not set,
> puppet would add default subjectAltNames to any non-CA cert it
> signed. The subjectAltNames were of the form:
> 
>  DNS:puppet, DNS:<fqdn>, DNS:puppet.<domain>
> 
> The fix for #2848, prevented implicit subjectAltNames from ever being
> added. However, this is desirable behavior when bootstrapping the
> initial puppet master.

This is a necessary fix, but the approach isn't perfect.  Josh is
going to rework it to better match our desire to have explicit rather
than implicit behaviour around SSL certificates and requests.

One thing that concerns me is that each face may need to replicate the logic below (which requires specifying the face specific section name to use and how to merge the properties in case of conflict). 
@user     = options[:username] || Puppet.settings[:dashboard_face_username]
This could cause problems if later the face is renamed, but the hard-coded section names are not. But more generally, it seems like something every face may want to do, but would have to replicate that logic. Another approach might be to have lib/puppet/application/face_base.rb create a settings hash, which is a merge of `Puppet.settings` with its face specific settings (based on the `face.name`), where the latter takes precedence. The settings hash, e.g. `@face.settings[:username]`, would then be available to each face, while the logic for merging the settings and deciding which section to use for that face is in one place. One problem I see is I'm not sure how the face would handle setting properties. Should a face be able to set properties that aren't in its category (either global or for a different face)?

In the case of #5794, it was never setting the owner/group, and it reapplied the same mode that it did previously, so that fix seems fine.

But this pull request changes the behavior non-trivially. It's probably the-right-thing-to-do, but it would really be helpful to call this out in the commit message, e.g. changing the mode from 755 to 750, otherwise, it's not clear that the change is intentional. Also, because of the security implications of not setting owner/group, it would also be helpful to explain why weren't setting them to the puppet user (moreso for group, because owner should be set based on the current user, which should be puppet I assume).
And, upon trying to do this again today, it seems like you need chronic=0.3 but you no longer need to force the version of ruby_parser. Go figure.

I'll take it out.  I don't think we actually need to do anything special since yum can understand packages with epochs in either `name-epoch:ver-rel.arch` or `epoch:name-ver-rel.arch` form, and the former should just work if people wish to specify the epoch as part of the ensure value instead of as part of the name.

```
package { 'foo':
  ensure => '1:1.2.3',
  provider => 'yum',
}
```

vs

```
package { '1:foo':
  ensure => '1.2.3',
  provider => 'yum',
}
```

Centos/RHEL/Fedora all use pip-python instead of pip -> It depend how you install pip. If you use `yum install python-pip` and install pip from epel then it is true. But if you install pip by easy_install `easy_install pip` then command is pip. Actual pip version from epel is 0.8, but using easy_install you are able use pip in version 1.2.1. 

Personally I prefer easy_install version. Right now I have to use pip-python on RHEL boxes because for RedHat osfamily puppet pip provider require pip-python command (I know I can make symlink pip to pip-python but it is dirty solution).

Thanks @jeffmccune I think the commit is just shining light on the fact that puppet should not be calling `Puppet::Module.new` on that file. For starters, it seems like we should only be calling `Puppet::Module.new` on directories. Can we also restrict it to a specific regex like we do in other parts of the PMT? /cc @hlindberg @jpartlow @hunner @andersonmills
It seems reasonable to restrict to directories here.  The Module itself validates the name according to a regex.
Yep, though as an FYI it is common to have a .git or .svn directory along side module directories in a modulepath directory.
I just started running into this as well.

The best is probably to have Puppet::Module answer if the reference is a valid name / loadable module - something like Puppet::Module.is_module?(name, path), this because we may later allow loading in different form than a directory, and the rules for names etc. is really best encapsulated in the Puppet::Module class (names may at some point contain more than just the name of the module etc.)
See also the comments on this PR: https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppet/pull/3318

@rlinehan @cprice404 do you know why this test and the corresponding `Request#to_s` method was removed?

@joshcooper that was me.  I did it because, other than this test, I didn't see anywhere where this behavior was relied upon, and I felt that the existence of the `to_s` method made it actively harder to debug things related to the indirector.  (Read: many different tickets I've worked on where I added a print statement to the request so I could see what it looked like, and thought it was a String because of the way that it printed.)

I personally feel that we're better off without it, but I don't care much, so if there's a reason why you think it's valuable I don't mind opening another PR to add it back in.

@cprice404 it looks like it was originally added in bd8d09747fd6c0dce89c17da41eb67ad92823cf7, and the error message has been moved around to https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppet/blob/master/lib/puppet/indirector/indirection.rb#L297. Does it mean the authorization message, where we interpolate the `"... on #{request}"`, will be less meaningful now?
I'll check.  If the error message is less meaningful I'd rather fix that w/o putting the 'to_s' back in, though, if that makes sense to you.

I just checked, and yes, it does seem to mean that this is error message is less meaningful. It also seems like it is used in https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppet/blob/master/lib/puppet/indirector/indirection.rb#L308. I can add it back but rename it something like `to_uri`.
Thanks @rlinehan, that sounds good to me.  Maybe call the method 'description'?  Since it's not always a URI?  Don't care too much about the name, personally, but my vote is for avoiding to_s.
@cprice404 @joshcooper I've opened https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppet/pull/3454 to add this back in.

i must disagree here :)

 i wrote this comment about the change you made to use the systemctl on debian 8, this break the jessie that did not have systemd packages. This change without testing the existance of systemctl make the following issue:

1/ force us to install all the systemd compatibility thing and add a bunch of unecessary packages so puppet do not choke on each 'service' statement
2/ see puppet choke and have it launch 'start' for each service each time it launch

as solution 1 add potential surface of attack and bug and also risk that a future upgrade mess things up by forcing the boot to use systemd on system where systemd cannot run ( because its a inii system and a cron system and a syslog system and a ntp system and whatever, next year i guess a x server too) and therefor cannot run everywhere (lxc, vserver and docker )  this change is a major issue for us.

why? Remember that there might be overrides so hash merges are more efficient which means that we have a hash anyway.

review_comments.body:
This is probably the thing I'm least happy with.

My first version didn't do any caching but had a noticeable (at least when running the tests) cost, because we were retrieving all facts every time someone asked for a fact.

I also considered making it easy to retrieve a single fact from the backing terminus, but this approach seemed much less evil.

I'm a touch uncomfortable relying on Facter for caching, because it essentially assumes that Facter's caching priorities will always match Puppet's, which isn't necessarily the case.

How would you do that?  This is the other area that's obviously questionable, but I couldn't come up with a better option, and if I had to choose between hard-coding Facter into the system and having a non-standard API for this, it was an easy choice.  It actually made me wonder if 'load' shouldn't become a standard part of the indirector - I could see other terminus types needing some kind of initialization method.

There are unfortunately a few places that need to explicitly cause facts to get loaded (e.g., after they're downloaded as part of pluginsync).

review_comments.body: After more research, both cygwin and vim strictly look at the FILE_PERSISTENT_ACLS flag when determining whether to get/set ACLs, ignoring the fstype. +# Load standard libraries

+# Define tool
+module Puppet
+  class Module
+    module Tool
+
+      # Directory names that should not be checksummed.
+      ARTIFACTS = ['pkg', /^\./, /^~/, /^#/, 'coverage']
+      FULL_NAME_PATTERN = /\A([^-\/|.]+)[-|\/](.+)\z/
+      REPOSITORY_URL = Puppet.settings[:module_repository]
+
+      # Is this a directory that shouldn't be checksummed?
+      #
+      # TODO: Should this be part of Checksums?
+      # TODO: Rename this method to reflect it's purpose?
+      # TODO: Shouldn't this be used when building packages too?
+      def self.artifact?(path)
+        case File.basename(path)
+        when *ARTIFACTS
+          true
+        else
+          false
+        end
+      end
+
+      # Return the +username+ and +modname+ for a given +full_name+, or raise an
+      # ArgumentError if the argument isn't parseable.
+      def self.username_and_modname_from(full_name)
+        if matcher = full_name.match(FULL_NAME_PATTERN)
+          return matcher.captures
+        else
+          raise ArgumentError, "Not a valid full name: #{full_name}"
+        end
+      end
+
+      # Read HTTP proxy configurationm from Puppet's config file, or the
+      # http_proxy environment variable.
+      def self.http_proxy_env

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,70 @@
+require 'pathname'
+require 'tmpdir'
+
+module Puppet::Module::Tool
+  module Applications
+    class Unpacker < Application
+
+      def initialize(filename, options = {})
+        @filename = Pathname.new(filename)
+        parse_filename!
+        super(options)
+        @module_dir = Pathname.new(options[:install_dir]) + @module_name
+      end
+
+      def run
+        extract_module_to_install_dir
+        tag_revision
+
+        # Return the Pathname object representing the directory where the
+        # module release archive was unpacked the to, and the module release
+        # name.
+        @module_dir
+      end
+
+      private
+
+      def tag_revision
+        File.open("#{@module_dir}/REVISION", 'w') do |f|
+          f.puts "module: #{@username}/#{@module_name}"
+          f.puts "version: #{@version}"
+          f.puts "url: file://#{@filename.expand_path}"
+          f.puts "installed: #{Time.now}"
+        end
+      end
+
+      def extract_module_to_install_dir
+        delete_existing_installation_or_abort!
+
+        build_dir = Puppet::Module::Tool::Cache.base_path + "tmp-unpacker-#{Digest::SHA1.hexdigest(@filename.basename.to_s)}"
+        build_dir.mkpath
+        begin
+          Puppet.notice "Installing #{@filename.basename} to #{@module_dir.expand_path}"
+          unless system "tar xzf #{@filename} -C #{build_dir}"
review_comments.body: This is a potential security hole: it will execute any instance of `tar` on the users path; can't we either do it in Ruby, or qualify the path for the platform?

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,75 @@
+module Puppet::Module::Tool
+
+  # = Modulefile
+  #
+  # This class provides the DSL used for evaluating the module's 'Modulefile'.
+  # These methods are used to concisely define this module's attributes, which
+  # are later rendered as PSON into a 'metadata.json' file.
+  class Modulefile
+
+    # Read the +filename+ and eval its Ruby code to set values in the Metadata
+    # +metadata+ instance.
+    def self.evaluate(metadata, filename)
+      returning(new(metadata)) do |builder|
+        if File.file?(filename)
+          builder.instance_eval(File.read(filename.to_s), filename.to_s, 1)
+        else
+          Puppet.warning "No Modulefile: #{filename}"
+        end
+      end
+    end
+
+    # Instantiate with the Metadata +metadata+ instance.
+    def initialize(metadata)
+      @metadata = metadata
+    end
+
+    # Set the +full_name+ (e.g. "myuser-mymodule"), which will also set the
+    # +username+ and module +name+. Required.
+    def name(name)
+      @metadata.full_name = name
+    end
+
+    # Set the module +version+ (e.g., "0.0.1"). Required.
+    def version(version)
+      @metadata.version = version
review_comments.body: If the metadata object doesn't, this should do syntax checking and fail with clear errors.

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,79 @@
+require 'net/http'
+require 'digest/sha1'
+
+module Puppet::Module::Tool
+
+  # = Repository
+  #
+  # This class is a file for accessing remote repositories with modules.
+  class Repository
+    include Utils::URI
+    include Utils::Interrogation
+
+    attr_reader :uri, :cache
+
+    # Instantiate a new repository instance rooted at the optional string
+    # +url+, else an instance of the default Puppet modules repository.
+    def initialize(url=Puppet::Module::Tool::REPOSITORY_URL)
+      @uri = normalize(url)
+      @cache = Cache.new(self)
+    end
+
+    # Return a Net::HTTPResponse read for this +request+.
+    #
+    # Options:
+    # * :authenticate => Request authentication on the terminal. Defaults to false.
+    def contact(request, options = {})
+      if options[:authenticate]
+        authenticate(request)
+      end
+      if ! @uri.user.nil? && ! @uri.password.nil?
+        request.basic_auth(@uri.user, @uri.password)
+      end
+      return read_contact(request)
+    end
+
+    # Return a Net::HTTPResponse read from this HTTPRequest +request+.
+    def read_contact(request)
+      begin
+        Net::HTTP::Proxy(
+            Puppet::Module::Tool::http_proxy_host,
+            Puppet::Module::Tool::http_proxy_port
+            ).start(@uri.host, @uri.port) do |http|
+          http.request(request)
+        end
+      rescue Errno::ECONNREFUSED, SocketError
+        raise SystemExit, "Could not reach remote repository"
+      end
+    end
+
+    # Set the HTTP Basic Authentication parameters for the Net::HTTPRequest
+    # +request+ by asking the user for input on the console.
+    def authenticate(request)
+      Puppet.notice "Authenticating for #{@uri}"
+      email = prompt('Email Address')
+      password = prompt('Password', true)
+      request.basic_auth(email, password)
+    end
+
+    # Return the local file name containing the data downloaded from the
+    # repository at +release+ (e.g. "myuser-mymodule").
+    def retrieve(release)
+      return cache.retrieve(@uri + release)
+    end
+
+    # Return the URI string for this repository.
+    def to_s
+      return @uri.to_s
+    end
+
+    # Return the cache key for this repository, this a hashed string based on
+    # the URI.
+    def cache_key
+      return @cache_key ||= [
+        @uri.to_s.gsub(/[^[:alnum:]]+/, '_').sub(/_$/, ''),
+        Digest::SHA1.hexdigest(@uri.to_s)
review_comments.body: Shouldn't this be a consistent hash with the other hashing we do in this code?
